keyTakeAways: A steel cable in the Lisbon Glória funicular failed to meet safety specifications and was not certified to carry passengers.
The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, causing a derailment and deadly crash.
Eyewitnesses described the descent as chaotic and out of control, with a loud bang and visible smoke.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as compliant despite non-compliance.
The funicular's operator, CARRIS, failed to ensure that the cable met its own operational standards.
The crash killed at least 16 people and injured several others.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly funicular crash in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, was caused by a steel cable that failed to meet safety specifications and was not certified for passenger use. The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, leading to a derailment, fatalities, and injuries. The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems, including falsified records of completed maintenance tasks. The operator, CARRIS, failed to ensure compliance with its own safety standards. Eyewitnesses described the incident as chaotic and terrifying, with one man named Bruno recalling a loud bang and visible smoke. While the interim findings are preliminary, the report highlights systemic failures in safety protocols and maintenance, prompting public concern about transportation safety in urban areas.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
